div.p: Occaſion'd by the lamented Fate of Viſcount George Auguſtus Howe, Baron of Clenawley, &c.
Who was Slain in the Battle near Carillon, July the 6th, 1758.
Together with an ODE, ON THE Reduction of LOUISBOURG, July 27, 1758.

q.l: Qui terram inertem, qui mare temperat

div.p: NEW-YORK: Printed by Parker and Weyman, 1758.

div.head: Advertiſement.
div.p: THE two following Odes were compos'd on their reſpective Occaſions, merely for the Author's Amuſement and the Entertainment of his Friends; but their Importunity and favourable, not to ſay partial, Judgment of them, have induc'd him to preſent them to publick View, not without ſome Hope, that they may meet with a kind Reception, if not by their intrinſick Merit, at leaſt by their Relation to thoſe important and intereſting Events which gave them Birth.

As the Life of Lord HOWE was unſpeakably valuable, ſo his Death is, and it were aſtoniſhing if it were not, moſt ſincerely and univerſally lamented: And indeed I know not, whether the ſad Cataſtrophe which ſucceeded his Fall, tho' attended with the Loſs of ſo many Lives, has occaſion'd more Regret, than the ſingle Fate of that illuſtrious and promſing young Hero. But the Reduction of Louiſbourg to his Britannick Majeſty muſt needs give inexpreſſible Pleaſure, and afford a moſt delightful Proſpect, to every one, in proportion as he apprehends its Importance to, and prizes the Welfare of, the Britiſh Colonies in America,

In this View of Things, and a critical Humour apart, the Author hopes theſe Performances with all their Faults (which he is ignorant of) may afford a pleaſing Entertainment to his Fellow Subjects, even at this Diſtance of Time; and if ſo, he wou'd have been glad if his Diſtance from the Preſs, &c. had not prevented their being ſomewhat more ſeaſonable.

If the Character of Lord HOWE be, as doubtleſs it is, incompleat it muſt be conſider'd that this Sketch of it was copied from the Voice of Fame; and if any Gentlemen of the Army or Navy ſeem to be neglected, or not mention'd according to their Rank, in the Ode on the Reduction of Louiſbourg, I hope it will be imputed rather to the Ignorance than the Partiality, of

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME, weeping Muſe, deſcend and bring
Thy well-known Lute, thy doleful Notes renew,Refering to ſome former Compoſitions occaſioned by publick Misfortunes.
With trembling hand ſtrike each complaining String,
(Thy drooping Brows crown'd with funereal Yew)
And in ſoft plaintive Numbers ſing
The hapleſs Fortune of the Brave,
The cruel Triumphs of the Grave,
With penſive Strains attend his Herſe,
And crown his Mem'ry with a grateful Verſe.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Come all ye gen'rous Souls that know,
What tis to feel a patriot Woe,
Whoſe Countries Loſſes make your Sorrows riſe,
Whoſe Boſoms bleed when Valour dies,
Deſcribes a Loſs ſo formidably great,
Give your ſoft Paſſions vent, and all diſolve in Woe.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: From diſtant Lands the Hero came,
His heart all glowing with a ſacred Flame
By no mean mercenary Hopes inſpir'd,
But bent on a diſintereſted Aim,
To ſave our ſinking Country from the Jaws of Fate.
To try the Chance of martial Strife,
And all the Dangers of the raging Main;
Danger and Toil in vain oppoſe his Way,
Our northern Regions to his View diſplay
Their frightful Wilds beheld him nobly dare,
Bound forth impetuous to the War,
Nor dread the awful Horrors of the wild Campaign.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Noble without a Thought of Pride,
HOWE well cou'd lay the Pomp of Life aſide
And fare as meanly as the rural Swain;
Tho' bred in all the Elegance of Taſte,
Th' unmanly Softneſs of the Age,
Nor wou'd he be a Gueſt
The Britiſh Int'reſt all his Care,
Refus'd the Pleaſures of the ſparkling Bowl,
And quench'd his Thirſt in the pure chryſtal Flood.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Vice in our Army long had held
And Guilt enormous with a fouler Stain
Than crimſon Seas of Blood, or Myriads of Slain.
Till, ſhock'd by Crimes of monſtrous Size,
The bluſhing Goddeſs, forc'd to yield,
And fled, a • erſt Aſtrea, to her native Skies.
But when kind Providence from far
Call'd HOWE, her Vot'ry, to the Field of War,
There ſhe reſum'd her former Throne,
There, in the midſt of Arms,
And clad the fav'rite Youth in glories like her own.
The Dictates of the heav'nly Maid,
And taught his Legions to confeſs her Sway;
And, by his great Example ſtruck with Awe,
Forſook the hallow'd Camp, or ſhunn'd the Face of Day.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Others cou'd plan the future War,
And triumph o'er the yet unconquer'd Foe:
Modeſt tho' valiant, and tho' youthful wiſe,
Young HOWE cou'd ſhine in Council too;
But he had Hands as well as Voice,
While others talk'd with mighty Noiſe,
The active HOWE was form'd to DO.
How glow'd with Love and Wonder every Heart,
When in each Toil he bore a Part,
In ev'ry Danger led the Way!
How did his great Example fire each Breaſt,
When he abridg'd his Hours of Reſt,
And in continual Labours worried out the Day!
Such were the Warriors of the Days of old,
Heroes like theſe extenſive Vengeance hurl'd
Had ſpoil'd the Temper of her Arms;
By Thunderbolts like theſe ſhe once ſubdu'd the World.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: If Heav'n had deign'd to ſpare
And put a period to the doubtful War:
We fondly hop'd to ſee thy Sword
Deal ſudden Vengeance on the Foe,
We hop'd to ſee our Rights reſtor'd,
And ſhout thee living and victorious home;
But ah! our pleaſing Dreams are o'er,
Our flatt'ring Proſpects are no more,
Our Hopes are buried in thy Grave,
Where is the Man, lamented HOWE!
Like thee to head our Army now,

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: But check thy paſſions, Muſe, and tell
How clos'd a Life employ'd ſo well,
How brave the Hero fought and how divine he fell.—
Behold! with what a noble Mien,
And bold as the fam'd Marlbro was,
His Sword the ardent Warrior draws,
Inſpiring with new Life his martial Bands,
Till the dire Ball, aim'd with delib'rate Art,
By ſome baſe Villain guiltier than the reſt,
Down ſinks the Hero to the Ground,
And as he falls he cries,
"Fight on my Friends, and truſt the Skies,
"Nor let your Courage languiſh, tho' your Leader dies;
"No; ſave your Country, and revenge my Death."—
He can no more.—Fate ſtops his Breath,
His Spirit iſſues in a Flood of Gore,
And HOWE, the great, the good, the valiant, is no more.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Curſe on the Wretch, that aim'd the fatal Ball!
And can ye, Britons, ſee your Leader fall
No, give the Wretch the Fate he gave,
Let him not triumph o'er the Brave;
But feel juſt Vengeance for an Hero ſlain.—
His Crime recoils upon his Head,
And down the Villain drops, to wait upon his Shade.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: But Thee, dear Youth, long ſhall thy Country mourn,
With grateful Tears bedew thy Duſt,
And future Ages, to thy Mem'ry juſt,
Shall dreſs with Glory thy diſtinguiſh'd Urn:
Long as theſe Regions know th' inſulting Gaul,
America ſhall ſtill deplore thy Fall;
And ſhine with Honour in the Rolls of Fame.

div.p: In the Advertiſement, in the 19th Line, read, (which he is not ignorant of)

div.head: An ODE, On the Surrender of Louiſbourg, July 27, 1758.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: At length the deſtin'd Blow is giv'n;
Our Cauſe is ſtill the Care of Heav'n.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The Palm to the victorious Foe,
When Waves can roll or Winds can blow?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: And gracious Heav'n at length repays
And bids us hope for happier Days.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Nor vainly glory in your Towr's;

lg.head: V.
lg.l: With your bold Taunts inſult the Brave;
"France in her turn has fed the Grave.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: No more regret our late Alarms;
Now ſing the Power of Britiſh Arms.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: And give your ſmiling Country Joy.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: And aid the Triumphs of my Song.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Who deigns to make our Land his Care,
The Lord of Hoſts the GOD of War.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: 'Tis He that makes our Sages wiſe;
And 〈◊〉 the Counſels of the Skies.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: He bids its raging Billows riſe;
And all the mighty Tumult dies.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: That ſweeps along the watry Waſle;
Or ſends the furious Northern Blaſt.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Well waſt our mighty Squadrons o'er;
Hnd reach at length the hoſtile Shore.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Rides out the Siege in ſolemn State;
To ſave her Louiſbourg from Fate.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: By Force to ward the dire Alarms;
To check the Progreſs of our Arms;

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: The Sov'reign Miſtreſs of the Flood:
The Fleet that boaſts a Guardian-God.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: And fires amid the wild uproar;
Fearleſs they climb the rocky Shore▪

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: In all their dreadful Horrors riſe;

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Fear and Confuſion on the Foe;

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Come and addreſs the Pow'r supreme;
And ſhout loud Honours to his Name:

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Like Clouds of Incenſe to the Skies.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: "How dreadful is a GOD in Arms!

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: "Thine is; and be the Glory Thine.—

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Our Chiefs, thoſe mighty Bolts of War,
And ſave the People of his Care.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: And prudent Zeal, Unus qui nobis cunctando restituis Rem.
Such Rays as grace the Hero's Name.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: And all grow great in Britain's Cauſe.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: Their Deeds with Honour ſhall rehearſe▪
Their Names embalm'd in lofty Verſe.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: Their Praiſe in rural Songs begin▪
And dreſs their Brows in living Green.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: Your thankful Thoughts and Tongues employ,
Britons, and give a Looſe to Joy.

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: And far reſound each Hero's Name:

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: And ſavage Nations dare no more
